review_title: Inflexible leadership, not committed to diversity, equity, inclusion and justice
pros: Hardworking campaign and support staff -- we hire great people who are dedicated and fun to work with.
cons: Leadership is inflexible and not adapting to the needs of their employees. Efforts to make our institution more inclusive, equitable and diverse have been cosmetic at best. Campaigns are determined with no consideration of environmental justice-- EJ is an after thought at best and efforts to incorporate justice in our work often feels performative.

pros: Dedicated professionals who are working hard to achieve meaningful change for the oceans.
cons: Compensation isn't quite competitive with peer organizations

review_title: Great opportunities for the short term
pros:
•	Oceana is filled with smart, passionate, kind staff. Everyone is friendly and knowledgeable. It’s a great place to learn from some of the best about ocean conservation and policy advocacy. 
•	Depending on your team, there is quite a bit of flexibility for staff to learn new skills. There are also amazing opportunities to attend interesting conferences, meet and work with staff from different international offices, or take professional development classes.
•	Its fun! The work is interesting and so are your coworkers.
cons:
•	The opportunities listed above are not necessarily distributed evenly. An individual's opportunity to take advantage of these things often depends on their own awareness/initiative and their supervisor. 
•	There is a severe lack of transparency around decision making in the organization. It’s unclear to staff why people at the same level across the organization are paid different salaries. If you want a promotion or raise, you must go through an exhausting process – lasting up to six months – where you are given inconsistent reasons as to why the organizations cannot pay you what you are asking. There have been many examples where some staff were told that what they were asking for was outside of their respective pay bands, while other staff pushing for the same position were told that there were no pay bands. Executive-level staff have even admitted that they do not understand how resources are allocated when it comes to these budgetary decisions.
•	There is no tangible commitment to values that executive leadership claim to care about. The first value is sustainability. Over my time there I watched passionate staff advocate for more sustainable office practices only to be consistently denied even an ear on the topic. The second and most notable are issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). Staff formed an interdisciplinary grassroots group in 2019 to discuss DEI issues within the organization, and generated positive momentum. However, once specific recommendations were shared with leadership, this momentum stalled. Executive leadership have chalked this up to HR not having the time to follow through on these recommendations, but they also haven’t prioritized building the team’s capacity to increase their bandwidth. Another example is ethics. Oceana has an ethics statement that staff are required to agree to when they are hired. One of the sections, which is typical in many organizations, is related to nepotism. During my time, there were at least four instances of children of donors, executive leadership, or board members given temporary or permanent positions. Multiple staff sent in anonymous complaints regarding some of these positions, only to receive copy and pasted responses that didn’t always align with the complaint they even sent in. 
•	 The structure of the organization doesn’t seem to match its growth and operations. The CEO and President are too involved in day-to-day tasks and, as far as staff can tell, have not developed any long-term strategic plan or vision for the organization. There is no clear structure or project management system in place to coordinate multinational or cross-cutting initiatives, which is becoming an increasing proportion of Oceana’s work. The current organizational structure likely served well when Oceana was a smaller organization roughly 10 years ago, but now it seems to hinder rather than support the existing growth. 


Individually, these challenges are not dealbreakers. Collectively, though, they compound. For example, the lack of transparency in decision making (especially around pay) makes it difficult for staff with less financial means to take or keep a job with Oceana, since there is no clear understanding of your future pay prospects. Retention in the organization is poor within certain teams, and especially in the mid to early career individuals. Things are certainly better now than when I started, but the pace is glacial and there was no sign that leadership was planning to actually invest (as in with budget, full time staff, and the humility it takes to relinquish some control) in fixing some of these problems. Perhaps most concerning is that HR has been made aware of all these issues, whether through anonymous complaints via the EthicsPoint platform, in exit interviews, or through specific, direct feedback from both current and former employees. It’s unclear if HR takes these complaints to senior leadership or not, but either way the improvement is happening too slowly. Even with the improvements, it all felt reactionary rather than proactive which is particularly frustrating for an organization that advocates against that exact behavior from national governments that refuse to sustainably manage their natural resources.

pros: good people at lower levels
cons: management is awful, very cliquey, and also not smart

pros: Strategic, goal-oriented, organization that makes a real impact on the issues it focuses on. The work-life balance is great, and colleagues are capable and kind.
cons: Underdeveloped digital engagement capacity, somewhat rigid approach.

pros: Good room for growth, good benefits
cons: It’s lots of desk work, but lots of interesting meetings and opportunities for professional discussion

review_title: Solid job, salary not commensurate with experience
job_title: Federal Policy Manager in Wheaton, IL
pros: Great immediate boss, exciting and rewarding work
cons: Salary does not increase with cost of living, increase benchmarks are unclear

pros: Good leaders and benefits and mission.
cons: Limited opportunity for advancement in some areas

pros: Everyone is great to work with
cons: unreasonable expectation to return to office

pros: benefits, free meals, accommodations and wifi
cons: Too much politics in the company

pros: Good salary, good team, and environment.
cons: Bad work schedule, and hours.

review_title: Needs to do more for justice
pros:
- Some really great people
- Advancing conservation
cons: - There is no focus on environmental justice in their work

pros: Everything, this place really cares about their employees
cons: None, it is truly a great place to work!

pros: Dedicated staff that are committed to the mission and how to achieve it using a range of tools.
cons: Living and working in D.C. isn't for everyone.

pros:
All round a great experience to work at this company.
Diverse people and product offering
cons: Could have done more in terms of career growth and pipeline

pros: Meaningful work with real environmental impact.
cons: High workload on a lot of top-down projects.

pros: Strong Benefits, Team Environment, Ample Financial Resources, Expert Staff, Paid Internships, Meaningful Campaigns
cons: Unrealistically High Expectations, Lengthy Review Processes, Lackluster Diversity and Inclusion Policies

review_title: Great place to work, not always easy, but great
pros: Oceana is an effective organization that is really helping to save the world's oceans. How cool is that? It is also a young organization and so employees get significant responsibility and the ability to build new ideas, digital efforts, campaigns and the like. Also, Oceana is international and you get to work with smart, interesting colleagues from Brazil, Chile, Canada, Spain, Belgium, Denmark, Belize, Peru, Philippines and more. And, the staff and management at Oceana are all impressive and smart and generally nice.  There is a core of long term managers and directors who are committed to the organization and have helped it achieve a lot.
cons: Oceana is growing fast and is very results driven. So, there are a lot of new projects, change and expectation of people achieving a lot. Everyone works hard. So, it can be rewarding but also hard work (and not always easy).  Also, because Oceana is a young organization there are a limited number of positions to advance into.  It is possible to move into new jobs but that often comes from growth. And, most of the training is on the job.

pros: Oceana’s overall mission has evolved to improving fisheries in major fishing nations with the ultimate goal of strengthening food security, an exceptional cause. The work can be engaging and dynamic. It can be great learning experience for someone with little to no conservation experience who wants to get their feet wet.
cons: Firstly, there is little room for advancement for early career individuals. The organization is top heavy, few positions in the middle, and numerous early-career folk. As many have commented before, leadership is poor and the very few early career people who are able to move up and receive a competitive salary are typically friends with their boss. Secondly, Oceana Headquarters DC is not the place for anyone who earned a doctorate. Someone with lower credentials, less work experience, but a friend of the boss will secure a better position than you. Unlike the other Oceana offices that place a higher value on science, the DC office will only hire a PhD when campaign/program wants to appear credible. Finally, salaries are not competitive with the market and there is a huge variance in salary for the same position within the organization.

pros: Purpose, motivation, challenge driven, good pay
cons: Can be se sexist sometimes

review_title: Overall a very welcoming and enjoyable company culture
pros: The people are great, the office is beautiful. A good place to work as a millennial.
cons: Compensation is less than exceptional, but what I expected

pros: people are awesome every day
cons: location could be more central yes

review_title: Run! Don't Walk, from Working Here.
pros: Some people are paid well.  The workplace decor is pleasant.  Great corporate mission.  Very intelligent and interesting staff.
cons: Depressing and unhappy work environment.  Nearly 1/2 the HQ staff has left in the past 12 months.  Severe disconnect between senior management and the rest of the staff = an "us vs. them" mentality.  Little room for growth for most staff, but an abundance of extra work.  Management walks the halls at 6 PM on a Friday to see who is in their seats.

review_title: Great people and great cause, with some flaws
pros: People dedicated to protecting the oceans; warm, collegial working environment; campaign structure that places priority on achieving tangible results; great work/life balance; very good compensation and benefits for a non-profit
cons: Corporate structure with very top-down management approach; very little interaction between departments; virtually no interaction with the board, including for campaign directors who are managing the work (board is too insulated from employees); management doesn't sufficiently value opinions of campaign directors and those below them; too much focus on achieving immediate tangible results, sometimes to the detriment of sound long-term policy

pros: Flexibility and good work/life balance.
cons: Management is highly centralized within executive team and all other employees from Middle Management down are not able to weigh in or drive the mission. It is an extremely adversarial work culture and departments do not support each other, rather they undermine the work of cross departmental colleagues. It is a culture of micro management like I have never seen before. I do not recommend this organization to career-minded people. Women may find it especially challenging. The turnover rates have been extremely high in the past 9 months and that should be a serious concern for anyone considering a position here.

pros: Great mission and strong scientific credentials. There's a really nice set of standards for how campaigns should be chosen and run (if they're followed). There are good office culture initiatives in place to encourage social interaction (DC office). The organization is growing a lot internationally.
cons: Getting the actual campaigning work done is difficult when leadership changes your priorities either seemingly on a whim or because a wealthy donor requests it. The organization needs to hire more people to deal with random requests or start standing up for their staff. Central control may have its benefits, but it seems no one will stand up to the CEO.

pros: Working to win tangible 3-5 year campaigns is challenging and exhilarating. My colleagues are dedicated, my team is supportive, and the work is fun. Managing a campaign is the sweet spot-- you are sheltered from the rigors of working directly with the VPs/CEO and the Board as well as other departments (like Development and Foundations), but you get to direct the course of the campaign and manage staff.
cons: The corporate structure can be challenging, and it is frustrating that the top 4 roles in the organization are filled by men. It can be difficult to move up in the organization as well. Salaries are weighted very heavily toward the top, and lower positions are not rewarded with raises very often.

pros: Employee benefits, parental leave policy, global organization, operating budget, great marine science network
cons: Inconsistent and inefficient performance review and salary increase recommendation process, upward mobility is limited, little to no professional development or training provided, lacks diversity and cultural awareness, too many manual processes, little recognition or value for entry-level staff and female managers

review_title: GREAT people, growing fast, paid internships but seize the opportunities as an intern
pros: I learned a lot as an intern about how a non-profit works and who all the players are that make things move. They really care about their interns, you get paid and even interact with high level personnel (CEO, directors, etc).
cons: Work gets redundant so I highly recommend asking if there are any tasks you can take on and show you are eager to learn. There are some tasks my boss had on a daily/weekly basis that I should have asked more about for a learning opportunity

review_title: Amazing mission, inspired employees, terrible leadership
pros: The mission and potential of the organization is unbelievable. The employees are truly dedicated and work like crazy to achieve their goals. You won't find an employee at Oceana that isn't seriously dedicated to the organization. There is also an amazing sense of camaraderie, support and genuine friendship among staff. The opportunities and responsibilities granted to employees are above average and you often feel like the work you do makes a real impact.
cons: It's a sinking ship right now. The leadership has driven the organization to a place where pretty much every person that works there (from entry level to director) has extremely low morale and is looking for a new job. There are multiple top leaders at Oceana that are unbelievably difficult to work for, and despite the revolving door of their direct reports and constant complaints to HR, nothing is done about it.  Most staff currently feel overworked and under appreciated, and like all that matters is the opinion of the board, CEO, and major donors.  The  upper level executives all blindly support each other and ignore the cry's for help from the general staff that make up the majority of the organization and do the bulk of the work.The extreme top down approach combined with the fact that some of the top execs have unbelievably poor managerial skills leads to an environment of jaded, disgruntled staff who despite having extreme passion for the mission and their jobs (as most people do at Oceana) they end up forced out in order to find an environment they can succeed, advance, and be rewarded in.

review_title: Invaluable environment to gain experience and learn how an advocacy group runs
pros:
Oceana was an incredible place to work as an entry level professional. The rapid growth and upward facing trajectory of the organization allows you to position yourself as an authority in your respective area. For instance,  you have the creative freedom to self start projects that contribute to the cause and establish clout. My time with the organization was crucial to the development and fostering of skills that helped me get to the next step in my career. 

To work for a non-profit (and a good one) is to do the job of 1.5-3 people at any given time. If you are comfortable with working hard for an amazing cause--alongside brilliant minds and a passionate team--Oceana is the right place for you.
cons:
- If you want hire a successful support staff, salaries should meet what other non profits are offering to entry level candidates 
-Salaries should also be raised at scale. Staff should not have to put on a show every year for this. The mission is a motivator to stay, but good staff will eventually leave if they are not paid competitively. 
- Remote working should not be a blanket "no", some staff benefit from these working conditions and have less productivity in an office space
- There seemed to be instances of sexism in the workplace, especially with women who are at "new mother" ages. This was not common among the internal orgs, however, management should listen to staff and understand that they may have unconscious biases

review_title: The free goldfish crackers weren't enough to keep me happy
pros: Good mission and causal work environment are the only things keeping this place afloat.
cons:
-Extremely poor communication across the organization
There is a lack of respect and teamwork between departments. Secrecy between departments is encouraged vs diplomacy. This leads to poor project management, metrics management, and individual needs of staff to be taken care of. The CEO and C-Suite does not update staff on the strategic plan of the organization – instead they spend their time telling staff how wonderful the board members are. Not only does this harm strategic planning and individual roles it also harms the work life of staff who are left in the dark and pitted against each other.

-Lack of vision
On the surface Oceana has a good mission. Implementation and pathways to achieve that mission are horrible.  The organization is stagnant. From the director level and up there are individuals who have been promoted beyond their capabilities or have stayed too long without updating their playbook to achieve results. The organization is so risk adverse that any new idea, particularly from someone young, is immediately looked upon as a risk not worth taking. Oceana’s campaigns are similar to others in the conservation space, yet others are outstripping Oceana in results on the local and national/international levels they work because they bring in a diverse workforce and ask diverse stakeholders to participate in saving the oceans and the natural world.  Oceana hasn’t fully won any of its campaigns in years without the help on the ground of their competitors. To win a victory by themselves would mean they took a risk and going it alone and making waves would be too risky. 

-High turnover
Oceana is not so small of an organization that upward mobility shouldn’t be a possibility for junior staff.   Staff leave for one of two reasons: no promotional opportunity or frustration with management (comms, strategy, not staying true to the mission). 

-Dated Professional knowledge, lack of investment in professional development
It’s possible to stay in a role for 5+ years and still be good at your job. Not true at Oceana. Most of Oceana’s upper management have been at the organization since it was in its infancy and have failed to remain knowledgeable about the competitive landscape. Others were promoted quickly and beyond their capacity have the privilege of staying in the roles, not meeting goals and having no consequences taken. The only real thing I learned here was that I had more knowledge than my supervisor and to put out dumpster fires caused by the supervisor between they spread to the team or harmed already weak inter departmental relationships.

-Board
Catering to the board is one thing but allow them to abuse the organization as a showcase in philanthropy to their friends and making it some feel good club where they can go out and eat shark fin soup and climb Machu Pichu isn’t worth the hassle. The board has failed to truly analyze the status of the organization. If they were then they would realize facts and figures are manipulated for their eyes for example the high turnover rate

-Favoritism
If a VP loves you, you can hide behind them and have your failures go unnoticed and blame your junior staff for wrongdoings. You can be promoted beyond your abilities.

review_title: Struggling with growing pains and management
pros:
- Benefits are descent. I don't pay anything for health, dental, or vision (single person). You have to grow vacation time, but you can gain about 3 weeks max with that limit increasing after 5 years.
- 401k matching is great.
- Depending on your job, you may get to travel to one of the many branch offices and conferences.
- Pretty fun group of coworkers and plenty of happy hours.
cons:
- Little to no room for advancement if you're in an entry level position.
- Unless you're one of the executive team members, salaries are low when compared to similar jobs in the area. Raises don't happen often even after you've provided proof that you've busted your butt and gotten positive results.
- Telecommuting and flexible work schedules are frowned upon by the top officials, so most employees are chained to their desks unnecessarily. It seems that you must quit before you're offered the ability to work remotely. This differs by department and, fortunately, I belong to one that allows me to occasionally work from home, but we have to be sneaky about it.
- Management training needs to be provided to those who are promoted to supervise others. Some of the senior staff and execs are beyond training and just need to be let go. Plenty of intelligent and talented people leave Oceana due to their managers.
- Management doesn't listen to the complaints of employees. The same issues come up every time we have the all staff meeting, but nothing is ever done.
- Too many people hired and given special treatment only because they are connected to one of the board members.
- Certain staff (I can't much without giving away my department) are treated like glorified personal assistants and it's mainly the executive team who is responsible for this. Recognized what my job entails and what it doesn't.

review_title: Great mission, No Opportunities to Grow
pros: Noble mission, supportive coworkers, highly-involved CEO, collaborative team
cons: Lack of opportunities to grow, lack of support from HR, unrealistic goals, unprofessional management

review_title: Do not work at Oceana! You will regret it !
pros: Good mission but you can support it as a donor vs wasting time working there
cons:
If you have decent experience do not be fooled and work here because of the cause.  There are many more healthy environmenrs to work in to advance your career.

Drama and caddy atmosphere; lack of advancement; micromanaging of employees; not reputable in DC market (versus other nonprofits to work for)

pros: Casual work environment, great mission.
cons: I have never been so unhappy in a job in my life. The coworkers are rude and cliquey - it was like being back in high school. Managers have ridiculous expectations and yet offer no room for growth or recognize employees for doing a good job. Extremely toxic work environment. Most of the people who work there don't have enough to do and shirk duties by spending time on social media or ignoring emails. High turnover due to poor management and lack of experience. If you want to work for a great nonprofit and change the world, go elsewhere. Oceana has an amazing mission but treats its employees horribly. You will be underpaid and overworked.

pros: In it's early days, Oceana was clear about filling a gap in the environmental world and the work was science-based and mission-driven. Marine biologists went on expeditions to chart urgent problems in commercial fishing stock and Oceana had a realistic approach to tackling problems that could be solved in a realistic time period. There were some great victories and the organization began to make a difference. There are still some terrific scientists and public policy people at Oceana and the mission is a good one.
cons:
Money can have a corrupting power, and as Oceana has been awarded some big grants, senior management has shown a remarkable arrogance that is rotting the organization from within. There is a belief that only the top people are worthy of  a hearing, and  there is no recognition that good ideas can come from all corners of the organization. Additionally, there is a sense that no one can do anything well, and that everything has to go through an exhaustive review.n. This cumbersome approach to management necessarily means that this once bold and original organization is now bloated and cumbersome. No one can show initiative; no one can move quickly. The layers of approval are endless and it leaves employees deflated. 

The executive team is secretive. Weekly meetings are held between all members of the executive team but staff members do not receive any kind of updates and the lack of communication within the organization will ultimately be a fatal flaw. There is no employee newsletter, nor any way of learning what one's colleagues are working on, making it impossible to be abreast of the strategies and priorities. This is really a problem as the priorities change as the money flows, and the focus that once was the strength or Oceana has been diluted by the opportunity to get money.

Finally, this place is a man's world. There is an undercurrent of sexism that I have never experienced anywhere else in the workplace. The CEO is pedantic and sexist as is the president. Male colleagues are treated like the boys in the band while the women are relegated to the groupie status. Screaming has been tolerated (!) and bullying is a daily occurrence.

review_title: Good Mission, Poor Management and Quality of Life
pros: Great benefits package, especially compared to other non profits. Good mission and unique view on ocean management, with their focus on restoring ocean fisheries to feed people and benefit biodiversity.
cons:
Expanding too quickly. Lots of buzz around opening offices in new countries without any top-level discussions about how service departments like fundraising and marketing will meet the extra demand and/or what they are actually responsible for. 

Poor work life balance. Upper-level management are incredibly inflexible: employees in the DC office are expected to be chained to their chairs for 9 hours a day, with little flexibility given for natural things like doctor's visits, difficult commutes, or family. The general vibe is that you'e always not working hard enough. 

Office moral in headquarters is very low. HR is helpful, but problems are never actually solved, especially pervasive problems with poor upper-level management. That being said, lower-level staff are incredibly supportive of one another, and they make the job tolerable day to day. 

Leadership often changes priorities of staff, either because of requests from wealthy donors or board members (mostly wealthy donors). I agree with other reviewers that the organization needs to hire more people to deal with these random requests or start standing up for their staff and protecting staff's ability to do heir jobs. 

The CEO is a smart man, but has blind spots when it come to extremely ineffective and universally disliked upper level management. Dysfunctional VPs drag their whole departments down, making it actively difficult for employees to do their jobs well. Upper level management does not trust the expertise of their employees. Employees often feel that when they do their job well, they are either punished by threatened management or are rewarded by more work that does not contribute to their goals. Additionally, very little consideration is given to career advancement, goals, or professional development, especially for younger workers. 

Not surprising, turnover is extremely high in many departments, even for nonprofits.

review_title: Sustainability In Our Oceans, But Not In This Company
pros: Oceana is seemingly a great place to work. In a vacuum, the work that I did day-to-day was rewarding and I felt like I was doing something for the greater good, and the benefits are decent for a nonprofit. The campaigns are very focused and the baseline for what Oceana is doing to save the oceans is something I was really able to get behind. The people I was able to work with were extremely passionate and made the long hours worth it. There are many great people you come in contact with and experiences that are great for growing in your respective field, but it is not sustainable. I was given much more work than my job description, which is great for someone just starting their career and wanting a lot of experience, but was never recognized for the extra work I was doing.
cons:
Overall, I would not recommend working here to anyone. 

Young professionals, especially women, are constantly striving to get an ounce of recognition for their hard work and, most of the time, it does not come at all.  Communication within departments, and throughout the entire organization, is extremely poor and it really hurts productivity and trust among employees. 

Promotions are rarely ever given, at least to the extent of which they are deserved, and the turnover is extremely high, especially in the lower level positions. Making employees BEG for a promotion every single year is inconsiderate and disrespectful of your employees who work extremely hard for the cause. Titles are inconsistent and even employees who meet all their goals are not properly compensated, and no explanation is ever given as to why certain promotions are given and others not.

review_title: Ineffective Policy Advocacy and Highly problematic Upper Management
pros: For the most part, everyone in the office was great to work with, smart, and hard working. The middle level management ("Campaign managers") I worked with were friendly, helpful, and motivating - but this was definitely not the case for all campaigns. The new HQ office location is convenient and modern.
cons:
Salary is nowhere near market, therefore turnover is more frequent than I've ever experienced. 
Campaign conservation "goals" were frequently not specific, achievable, nor relevant, The organization markets itself as the largest ocean conservation organization in the world, yet I cannot point to a signal policy "win" achieved by Oceana. After working in the NGO and policy space for years, it's no secret that among the eNGO community, Oceana not thought highly of in terms of respect or effectiveness. 

Ultimately, the organization is mostly focused on increasing its recognition among celebrities and the general public to raise funding - not to put those resources towards making actual change and influencing public policies. The number of clicks/likes/retweets in no way translates to sound conservation work. Don't be fooled.

review_title: Employer is a fast-paced growing advocacy group.
pros: Employees have the opportunity to work with passionate people, engage with challenging problems, and use their skills to work in teams to make a real difference.
cons: The non-profit sector has a lower salary scale than equivalent for-profits, is not subject to market discipline correcting problems, and may have less room for internal career advancement.

pros: Notoriety, friendly atmosphere, on-the-job training and professional development opportunities, good benefits, travel opportunities, interesting and novel issues.
cons: High turnover rate, little room or tolerance for individuals to take initiative, few opportunities for internal advancement, professional degree may not ensure comparable compensation.

pros: In a great location, doing great work to save the oceans. Very nice people who were supportive when it came to finding my next job
cons: Poor management structure. There should be more people in between interns and the VP of xxx. Salary could be a bot higher

review_title: Better run than many non profits
pros: Efficiently run; great colleagues; social activities; seeing results from your work
cons: No employee development programs or education benefits (common for a non profit)

pros: A group of dedicated staff that are committed to protecting our oceans
cons: Oceana has a proven approach to its work. New staff that don't understand or appreciate how Oceana works are often frustrated

review_title: Making A Difference Alongside GREAT People
pros: Passion, enthusiasm, team-oriented atmosphere, open floor plan, collaborative brainstorm sessions, fun happy hours, learn something new everyday.
cons: I do not feel that there were any downsides to working at Oceana.

pros:
- Very focused campaign missions (~3 year timelines) with generally well defined goals
- Friendly work environment
cons:
High turnover rate
Little room for advancement 
Pay is significantly lower than the market (for most all positions)
Large disconnect between the CEO and other leadership

pros: Fun dedicated people, great office environment.
cons: Issues between upper level management and the rest of organization.

pros: The focus on discrete campaigns makes for a very innovative almost start-up type atmosphere in how projects are developed and executed
cons: The cross-department communication is not as effective as it could be

review_title: Inspiring Mission and Committed to Employees
pros: Authentic, caring leaders; committed to supporting employees; business-like approach to getting results; good benefits; strong financial position
cons: Internal communications needs attention; a few poor leaders need to be addressed

pros: Very smart people on a mission
cons: Depends on the department you work on some are badly managed

pros: Great people and a fun office culture.  People always looking to help and there is lots of collaboration between departments.
cons: Not too many bad things to say.

pros: Great place to work.  Very rewarding and awesome people.
cons: More training for new employees would be helpful.

pros: The location is great, that's about it.
cons:
Poor culture, inexperienced and arrogant middle managers, hyper-competitive, limited options for career growth, zero diversity,  unfair compensation, HR department is useless -- seriously they suck, leadership is completely detached from teams, lots of secret meetings, a ton of turnover. One day you'll see someone, the next they're gone.

I found a better opportunity within policy on the hill.

pros: Great leadership and mission. Fun working environment.
cons: It's a nonprofit so your not going to make a huge salary. They do try and make up for it with benefits and a good working environment.

pros: Fun and encouraging..Good money and fantastic benefits...family atmosphere..good prospects and promotion...a fair company
cons: Can get very busy so always doing overtime but the money is great fior this....late finshes and very esrly starts

pros:
Great benefits
Great mentors
Leadership is friendly, helpful, and concerned with your future career
Inclusion in important events
Exposure to policy
cons: Pay is low for living in DC

pros: Well known company in the field, great for contacts and resume building, good mission values and purpose.
cons: Poor management, poor investment in employee advancement, slow results, poorly defined purpose and mission inside of teams.

review_title: Great organization, not a lot of room for upward mobility among interns/fellows
pros: Good supervisors, meaningful work, company values work/life balance
cons: Interns and fellows don't have many opportunities to become full-time employees

pros: Mission driven work, friendly work environment, good work-life balance
cons: Little room for advancement from entry level positions.

pros: Fun co-workers and lots of social events.
cons: Little room for advancement; high turnover.

job_title: Cluster Revenue Manager in Bournemouth, England
pros: great , team work , helpful , carriere step up
cons: long hours , leisure driven , great place to work

pros: Excellent team of smart people
cons: Old school structure and not diverse

pros: interesting projects, great mission, some fun colleagues
cons: long hours, some inconsistency from management

pros: Good and interesting work, social atmosphere.
cons: Interns are paid except for law clerks and legal fellows.

pros: Depends on your boss and role.
cons: Hardest part to win concrete policy victories is the executive committee and the board.
